entry.title: npm security update: Attack campaign using stolen OAuth tokens
entry.summary: npm's impact analysis of the attack campaign using stolen OAuth tokens and additional findings.

entry.title: How we use Dependabot to secure GitHub
entry.summary: A two-part story about how GitHub’s Product Security Engineering team rolled out Dependabot internally to track vulnerable dependencies, and how GitHub tracks and prioritizes technical debt.

entry.title: Announcing TypeScript 4.7
entry.summary: Today we’re excited to announce the availability of TypeScript 4.7! The post Announcing TypeScript 4.7 appeared first on TypeScript.

entry.title: Improved REST API documentation
entry.summary: We’re excited to announce some big improvements to our REST API documentation. We know developers rely on this documentation to integrate with GitHub, and we are committed to making it trustworthy, easy to find, and easy to use.

entry.title: GitHub Sponsors launches in India
entry.summary: GitHub Sponsors is now available to all developers in India – no more waitlist, you can sign up right away!

entry.title: Eight years of the GitHub Security Bug Bounty program
entry.summary: It was another record year for our Security Bug Bounty program. We're excited to highlight some achievements we’ve made together with the bounty community from 2021!

entry.title: Release Radar · April 2022 Edition
entry.summary: Each month, we highlight open source projects that have shipped major updates. These include everything from world-changing technology to developer tooling, and weekend projects. Here are our top staff picks on projects that shipped major version releases in April. Flyte 1.0 I was lucky enough to discover Flyte during Hacktoberfest last year. Now, Flyte has […]

entry.title: Action needed by GitHub Connect customers using GHES 3.1 and older to adopt new authentication token format updates
entry.summary: Upgrade to GHES 3.2 or newer by June 3rd to continue using GitHub Connect.

entry.title: Math support in Markdown
entry.summary: Mathematical expressions are key to information sharing amongst engineers, scientists, data scientists, and mathematicians. Today we are pleased to announce that math expressions can be rendered in Markdown on GitHub using $$ as a delimiter for code blocks with math content or the $ delimiter for inline math expressions.

entry.title: How we’re continuing to enable all developers to build
entry.summary: Learn about what GitHub is doing to make their products more inclusive, and what’s next.

entry.title: Securing and delivering high-quality code with innersource metrics
entry.summary: With innersource, it’s important to measure both the amount of innersource activity and the quality of the code being created. Here’s how.
